attr.q: Do the same for the product (x_ny_n).
attr.a:
Given \epsilon, there exits N such that for all n and m that are bigger than N, e.i., N < m,n, following holds

|x_n - x_m| = \epsilon_x < \epsilon \\ |y_n - y_m| = \epsilon_y < \epsilon

Then

\begin{aligned} & | x_ny_n - x_my_m | \\ & = | x_my_m - x_ny_n | \\ & = |(x_n+\epsilon_x)(y_n+\epsilon_y) - x_ny_n| \\ & = | \epsilon_xy_n + x_n\epsilon_y + \epsilon_x\epsilon_y | \\ & \leq | \epsilon_xy_n | + | x_n\epsilon_y | + |\epsilon_x\epsilon_y | \\ & \leq | \epsilon y_n | + | x_n\epsilon | + |\epsilon^2 | \end{aligned}

Cauchy sequence is bounded. Say bound of (y_n) is Y and (x_n)'s X.

\cdots \\ \begin{aligned} & \leq | \epsilon Y | + | X\epsilon | + |\epsilon^2 | \end{aligned}

The last equation can yield to any real number.
